title: 200 Delegates and a Conference Hall
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"200 delegates attend a conference is held in a hall. The hall has 7 doors, marked "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A,B,\ldots, G"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". At each door, an entry book is kept, and the delegates entering through that door sign it in the order in which they enter. If each delegate is free to enter any time and through any door he likes, how many different sets of seven lists could arise in all?                                                                                                                "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If the answer can be expressed an "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"^nP_k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some positive integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n,k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", find (the minimium value of) "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n+k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Details and Assumptions","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":":"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Assume that every person signs only at his first entry.                            "}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large ^nP_k=\dfrac{n!}{(n-k)!}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Suppose that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"D"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" delegates go through "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" doors. Consider the numbers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1,2,3,\ldots,D"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" copies of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Since the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" copies of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are indistinguishable, there are
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{(D+d-1)!}{(d-1)!} \; =\; {}^{D+d-1}P_D "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
ways in which these symbols can be ordered."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The list of numbers before the first "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the list of delegates through the first door (in order). The list of numbers between the first "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and the second "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the list of delegates through the second door (in order), and so on. Thus
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" {}^{D+d-1}P_D "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
is the number of possible sets of signing-in lists."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In the case that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"D=200"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d=7"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the number of signing-in lists is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{}^{206}P_{200}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", making the answer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{406}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            A very easy solution to understand. Upvoted(+1)

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let a,b,c,d,e,f,g be the number of persons entering through the A,B,C,D,E,F,G respectively. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Then, "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
 a+b+c+d+e+f+g=200 "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Therefore number of ways of dividing 200 into 7 parts ="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" ^{7+200-1} C _{200} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"^{206}C_{200}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"^{206}C_6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
 The total number of ways of dividing 200 persons into 7 sets containing a,b,c,d,e,f,g persons repectively 
="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{200!}{a!b!c!d!e!f!g!} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
But the persons in the set of door A can be arranged in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ways. Same holds for the other sets. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
So, total number of ways of dividing 200 persons into 7 sets = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{200!}{a!b!c!d!e!f!g!} \times a!b!c!d!e!f!g! "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"200!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \therefore"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" Required number ="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" ^{206}C_{200} \times 200!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"= "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \boxed{^{206}P_{200}} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                            There is a one line solution to this problem."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hint:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" Modify the "},{"type":"text","text":"stars and bars","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" approach to permutations.

title: 200 Follower Problem
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Call a natural number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" faithful if there exist natural numbers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a<b<c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a|b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b|c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=a+b+c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Find the sum of all natural numbers which are not faithful."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"There is an easy criterion for determining whether a positive integer is faithful."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"blockquote","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
  "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Lemma.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" A positive integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is faithful if and only if it has a divisor "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n/a - 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a composite number greater than "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"
  
  "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Proof.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" By definition, a positive integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is faithful if and only if there exist integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"s"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r,s \geq 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a + ar + ars = n \iff a[1 + r(1 + s)] = n \iff r(1 + s) = \frac na - 1."}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r,s \geq 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the left side of equation on the right is simply a general representation for a composite number greater than "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We claim that all integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n > 40"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are faithful. To show this, choose the largest value "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k \in \{0,1,2,3,4\}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n = 2^k d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k \leq 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is odd since otherwise we could have chosen a larger value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Put "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a = 2^k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac 1a \geq \frac 18 \implies d = \frac na > \frac {40}8 = 5 \implies d - 1 = \frac na - 1 > 4."}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is odd in this case, the relation on the right shows "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n/a - 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is even and greater than "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and thus composite. If instead "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k = 4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then put "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a = d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac na - 1 = 2^4 - 1 = 15,"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" which is a composite number greater than "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". In either case, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n/a - 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is composite and greater than "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is faithful based on our lemma. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now we have shown that we only need to consider positive integers less than or equal to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"40"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to find all the non-faithful numbers, and the lemma is a convenient enough way to check for faithfulness. Nine numbers turn out not to be faithful, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\text{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 12, 24},"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" and the sum of these numbers is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{65}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 200+ followers (easy version)
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/solvable/2b7b41db9d.af4552e64a.imOE6x.jpg?width=250"}},{"type":"text","text":"
Calvin thinks of a 5-digit number. The product of the digits is 200."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"How many different numbers which Calvin could have thought of? "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Try the harder version at here"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We note that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"200 = 2^3\times 5^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  There are only "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" possible combinations and the respective permutations are as follows:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{array} {rrrr} \text{Combination} & & \text{Permutations} \\ 11558 & \Rightarrow & \dfrac{5!}{2!\times 2!} = \dfrac{120}{4} & = 30 \\ 12455 & \Rightarrow & \dfrac{5!}{2!} = \dfrac{120}{2} & = 60 \\ 22255 & \Rightarrow & \dfrac{5!}{2!\times 3!} = \dfrac{120}{12} & = 10 \\ \hline & & \text{Total:} & 100 \end{array} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The total number of such 5-digit numbers is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{100}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
